PAL.NAME: TMG 2010
PAL.DESCRIPTION: General threshold file for Microsoft Thread Managment Gateway (TMG) 2010

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Waiters

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Netlogon(_Total)\Semaphore Waiters

THRESHOLD.NAME: Critical more than 2
THRESHOLD.CODE:
StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfNetlogonSemaphoreWaiters -Operator 'ge' -Threshold 2
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Number of thread currently waiting to acquire the semaphore. The number of the thread that is waiting to obtain the semaphore. This value should remain at 0 at all times. Short bursty spikes are OK to see as that simply means that we had a large amount of requests which were handled in a short period of time.
More info: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/928576

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Holders

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Netlogon(_Total)\Semaphore Holders

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Number of thread currently holding the semaphore. How many threads on average are holding the client semaphore. This is the number of threads trying to get a netlogon session to a DC that are Blocked. Blocked could be locked open by a process, network down, etc. when semaphore waiters is non 0, some local process is waiting on lsass for a response and the lsass thread is blocked
More info: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/928576

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine Active Connections

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine - Active Connections

THRESHOLD.NAME: Warning if greater than 50k concurent active connectioins
Critical if more than 100k concurent active connections

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The total number of active connections currently passing data.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine Backlogged Packets
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of packets waiting for the firewall packet engine to create a data pump.

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine - Backlogged Packets

THRESHOLD.NAME: Warning if more than 2 packets losted
Critical if more than 10 packets were lost

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine Dropped Packets/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine - Dropped Packets/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of packets dropped by TMG per second. Value should be under 200.Should be coreleted with other collected counters from Firewall Packet Engine

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine ReInject Available IRPs
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine\ReInject Available IRPs

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine\ReInject Available IRPs
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine\ReInject Available IRPs

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine - ReInject Available IRPs
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Firewall Packet Engine\ReInject Available IRPs

THRESHOLD.NAME: Critical if lower than 5. It's mean that we have only free buffer for local(TMG) demand

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
The number of reinject available IRPs. Value of 50 is the default result. By default it reserves 10% of the re-injection threads for localhost traffic, so smaller than 5 is considered bad. Value should be always above 20 (in average). TMG by default it reserves 10% of the re-injection threads for localhost traffic. If that counter is small you should compare it with authentication and name resolution counters.
To enable this counter you need to add the following registry entry:
Location: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\RAT\Stingray\Debug\FWSRV
Key: FWS_PRIVATE_PERFORMANCE_COUNTERS
Type: DWORD
Value: 1
The restart is not neccesary.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Cache\Disk Failure Rate Disk Failure Rate (failures/sec)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Disk Failure Rate (failures/sec)

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of I/O failures per second since the Firewall service started. An I/O failure occurs when Forefront TMG fails to read from or write to disk cache.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy HTTPS connection inspection/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\HTTPS connection inspection/sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\% HTTPS inspection failures/sec
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\% HTTPS inspection failures/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate per second at which HTTPS connections are inspected.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy Active Web Sessions

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Active Web Sessions

THRESHOLD.NAME: Warning if there is mostly only one active Web Session.
THRESHOLD.CODE:
StaticThreshold -CollectionOfCounterInstances $CollectionOfForefrontTMGWebProxyActiveWebSessions -Operator 'le' -Threshold 1
#// The -Operator parameter accepts gt for greater than, ge for greater than or equal to, lt for less than, #// and le for less than or equal to. -Threshold is the static value for the threshold.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of active Web sessions currently connected to Forefront TMG.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Cache Hit Ratio for Last 10K Requests (%)

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The percentage of Web Proxy client requests served using cached data out of the total number of Web Proxy client requests to the Forefront TMG, for the last 10,000 requests serviced. Shows the amount of requests served from the cache as a percentage of total successful requests serviced. This ratio is the same as that measured by the Cache Hit Ratio counter. The difference between these two counters is that the Cache Running Hit Ratio counter measures this ratio for the last 10,000 requests serviced, and the Cache Hit Ratio counter measures this ratio since the last time that Web proxy was started. This means that the Cache Running Hit Ratio counter gives a more dynamic evaluation of cache effectiveness. If lower than 5% Cache not used - Consider If higher than 95% should be increased.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy Average Milliseconds/request

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Web Proxy - Average Request time in miliseconds

THRESHOLD.NAME: Warning if response time equal or higher than 20 sec.
Critical if response time is greater than 30000

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the mean number of milliseconds required to service a Web Proxy client request, not including requests serviced by the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) tunnel. This counter can be monitored at peak and off-peak times to get a comprehensive picture of the rate at which client requests are being serviced. A counter with a value that is too high might indicate that the TMG computer is having difficulty in handling all requests and that requests are being delayed. It shouldn’t be over 30000 for longer than couple minutes. Review policy and check whether it is possible to use stateful filtering instead of application filtering for traffic that is considered harmless.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy Current Cache Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Cache Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The mean number of milliseconds required to service a Web Proxy client request from cache (not including tunneled requests for HTTPS or SNEWS).

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Cache Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Cache Fetches Average Milliseconds/request

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Web Proxy - Average Current Cache Fetches Request time in miliseconds
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Cache Fetches Average Milliseconds/request

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Web Proxy - Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Current Direct Fetches Average Milliseconds/request

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The mean number of milliseconds required to service a Web Proxy client request directly to the Web server or upstream proxy (not including tunneled requests for HTTPS or SNEWS).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for HTTP Requests (%)

THRESHOLD.NAME: If less than 20% for long period
Critical if more than 30% for long period

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Percentage of memory available for HTTP requests. When an HTTP request is made, Forefront TMG uses memory from a pre-allocated pool. You can use the ProxyVmemAlloc3pSize registry value in the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\W3Proxy\Parameters registry key to modify the size of this pool.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Memory Pool for SSL Requests (%)

THRESHOLD.NAME: Warning if less than 30% in avg.

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Percentage of memory available for SSL requests. When an SSL request is made, Forefront TMG uses memory from a pre-allocated pool. You can use the ProxyVmemAlloc1pSize registry value in the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\W3Proxy\Parameters registry key to modify the size of this pool.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy Total Failing Requests

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Web Proxy -Total Failing Requests

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the total number of requests that have failed to be processed by Web proxy because of errors. Errors can be the result of Web proxy failing to locate a requested server URL on the Internet or because the client did not have authorized access to the requested URL. This counter should be lower than the Total Successful Requests counter. If not, it is an indication that TMG is failing to service requests effectively. This could be a configuration problem, or a connection that is too slow. It could also indicate an access policy that is too restrictive.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service Available Worker Threads

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - Available Worker Threads

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of Firewall Service worker threads that are available (waiting in completion port queue).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service Worker Threads

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - Worker Threads

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of Firewall Service worker threads that are currently alive. A value higher for Worker Threads than 400 is considered bad

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service DNS Cache Hits %

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - DNS Cache Hits

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The percentage of DNS domain names retrieved from the DNS cache, out of a total of all DNS entries retrieved from the Firewall Service.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service Accepting TCP Connections

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - Accepting TCP Connections

THRESHOLD.NAME: Possible attack from Firewall clients or congestion on the Internal network

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of connection objects waiting for a TCP connection from the Firewall client after a successful remote connection. If over 10 could indicates an attack from Firewall clients or congestion on the Internal network

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service Pending DNS Resolutions

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - Pending DNS Resolutions

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of Winsock gteaddrinfo() calls pending. These are calls used to resolve host DNS domain names and IP addresses for firewall service connections. Pending DNS resolutions can impact pending TCP connections. Windows should perform resolutions quickly & reliably – especially for domain-based DNS.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Firewall Service Pending TCP Connections

CHART.CHARTTITLE: Forefront TMG Firewall Service - Pending TCP Connections

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the total number of pending TCP connections. This is the total number of connections that are waiting for a connect call to finish. High number may indicate a flood attack or worm propagation to random IP addresses when there is a policy rule that restricts access to one or more destinations specified by domain names.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$ISARS:Buffer Manager Lazy writes/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSSQL$ISARS:Buffer Manager\Lazy writes/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of buffers written by buffer manager's lazy writer. This counter tracks how many times a second that the Lazy Writer process is moving dirty pages from the buffer to disk in order to free up buffer space. Generally speaking, this should not be a high value, say more than 20 per second or so. Ideally, it should be close to zero. If it is zero, this indicates that your SQL Server's buffer cache is plenty big and SQL Server doesn't have to free up dirty pages, instead waiting for this to occur during regular checkpoints. If this value is high, then a need for more memory is indicated. As at default configuration it's sql express edition and memory usege is restricted, should be considered change for a standalone SQL.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$MSFW:Buffer Manager Lazy writes/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSSQL$MSFW:Buffer Manager\Lazy writes/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of buffers written by buffer manager's lazy writer. This counter tracks how many times a second that the Lazy Writer process is moving dirty pages from the buffer to disk in order to free up buffer space. Generally speaking, this should not be a high value, say more than 20 per second or so. Ideally, it should be close to zero. If it is zero, this indicates that your SQL Server's buffer cache is plenty big and SQL Server doesn't have to free up dirty pages, instead waiting for this to occur during regular checkpoints. If this value is high, then a need for more memory is indicated.As at default configuration it's sql express edition and memory usege is restricted, should be considered change for a standalone SQL.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Forefront TMG Web Proxy % Failing Requests/sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\Failing Requests/sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Forefront TMG Web Proxy\% Failing Requests/sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The rate per second of requests that have failed because of some type of error.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$MSFW:Buffer Manager:Page life expectancy

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSSQL$MSFW:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy

THRESHOLD.NAME: Page life expectancy is less than 5 minutes (300 seconds)

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Number of seconds a page will stay in the buffer pool without references. This performance monitor counter tells you, on average, how long data pages are staying in the buffer. If this value gets below 300 seconds, this is a indication that SQL Server is doing too many logical reads putting pressure on the buffer pool or potentially that your SQL Server could use more memory in order to boost performance. Anything below 300 is a critical level. The Page life expectancy counter is considered one of the most critical counters for SQL Server. If Page life expectancy becomes low SQL Server will attempt physical reads from disk into the buffer pool to honor requests. Requests from physical disk will take considerably longer causing higher disk
If Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy is low then the Buffer Manager\Lazy Writes /sec will be higher as the Lazy Writer will become active attempting to free the buffer cache as SQL Server will be under memory pressure. Due to the disk impact of the physical reads incurred, the \Physical Disk \Avg. Disk sec/Read counter may also become a bottleneck as SQL Server is reading from disk instead of the buffer pull to honor requests. Look for an increase in SQL Server:Buffer Manager: Lazy Writes/sec performance object counters because SQL starts to flush pages out of the buffer pool cache under memory pressure.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$ISARS:Buffer Manager:Page life expectancy

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSSQL$ISARS:Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Number of seconds a page will stay in the buffer pool without references. This performance monitor counter tells you, on average, how long data pages are staying in the buffer. If this value gets below 300 seconds, this is a indication that SQL Server is doing too many logical reads putting pressure on the buffer pool or potentially that your SQL Server could use more memory in order to boost performance. Anything below 300 is a critical level. The Page life expectancy counter is considered one of the most critical counters for SQL Server. If Page life expectancy becomes low SQL Server will attempt physical reads from disk into the buffer pool to honor requests. Requests from physical disk will take considerably longer causing higher disk
If Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy is low then the Buffer Manager\Lazy Writes /sec will be higher as the Lazy Writer will become active attempting to free the buffer cache as SQL Server will be under memory pressure. Due to the disk impact of the physical reads incurred, the \Physical Disk \Avg. Disk sec/Read counter may also become a bottleneck as SQL Server is reading from disk instead of the buffer pull to honor requests. Look for an increase in SQL Server:Buffer Manager: Lazy Writes/sec performance object counters because SQL starts to flush pages out of the buffer pool cache under memory pressure.

THRESHOLD.NAME: Page life expectancy is less than 5 minutes (300 seconds)
